title: John Duggan (rugby)
text:
John "Johnny" Duggan (birth registered first ¼ 1929) is an English former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, and professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1940s and 1950s. He played club level rugby union (RU) for <a href="Wakefield%20RFC">Wakefield RFC</a>, as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Wing">wing</a>, i.e. number 11 or 14, and representative level rugby league (RL) for <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Yorkshire</a>, and at club level for <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Wakefield%20Trinity%20players">Heritage № 569</a>), as a , i.e. number 2 or 5.
Background.
Johnny Duggan's birth was registered in <a href="Wakefield">Wakefield</a> district, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, England.
Playing career.
At the age of 13, Duggan played <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Fly-half">Stand-Off/Fly-half</a>, and captained St Austin's school but he didn't play any further rugby until leaving school at 16 when he joined <a href="Wakefield%20RFC">Wakefield RFC</a> as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Wing">wing</a>. In the 1945/46 season, he scored three tries in four appearances. The following season saw fourteen tries in twenty-two games. the 1947/48 season was his last amateur season, he played three games in 1947 scoring two tries.
He signed for <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> at Christmas 1947 when he was 18. In his first full season for Trinity, he made 28 appearances and scored seventeen tries, four of them in one game against the <a href="Featherstone%20Rovers">Featherstone Rovers</a>.
The Wakefield Express described how he became a firm favourite with the <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> crowd for 
"his strong running, elusiveness and never say die temperament"
In September 1949, he was selected to play for <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Yorkshire</a> but had to withdraw having broken his nose in a game against <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a>.
County honours.
Johnny Duggan played , i.e. number 2, in <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Yorkshire</a>'s 3–12 defeat by <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Lancashire</a> in the <a href="1949%20Rugby%20League%20County%20Championship">1949</a> <a href="County%20Championship%20%28rugby%20league%29">County Championship</a> Final during the <a href="1948%E2%80%9349%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1948–49 season</a> at <a href="Thrum%20Hall">Thrum Hall</a>, <a href="Halifax%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Halifax</a> on Tuesday 3 May 1949, in front of a crowd of 7,000.
County Cup Final.
Johnny Duggan played , i.e. number 2, in Wakefield Trinity's 17–3 victory over <a href="Keighley%20Cougars">Keighley</a> in the <a href="1951%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1951</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1951%E2%80%9352%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1951–52 season</a> at <a href="Fartown%20Ground">Fartown Ground</a>, <a href="Huddersfield">Huddersfield</a> on Saturday 27 October 1951.
Johnny Duggan emigrated to New Zealand in the early 1950s and began playing rugby union again, and on Saturday 19 July 1952 the <a href="Wakefield%20Express">Wakefield Express</a> carried the headline, "Johnny Duggan to tour with New Zealanders?", in the article Johnny Duggan stated "I have filled in a form for reinstatement in a rugby union club and the <a href="Wanganui%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Wanganui</a> officials are backing me up. If it comes through there is every likelihood of seeing me in England with the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a> touring team next season – at least, that is what the locals says who have been very impressed with my displays in practice", however he did not participate in the <a href="1953%E2%80%9354%20New%20Zealand%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20Britain%2C%20Ireland%2C%20France%20and%20North%20America">1953–54 New Zealand rugby union tour of Britain, Ireland, France and North America</a>.
